main.title: About The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO)
main.html:
ISRO is the national space agency of India, headquartered in Bengaluru. It operates under the Department of Space (DOS), which is directly overseen by the Prime Minister of India.

ISRO is one of the world's leading space agencies, known for its cost-effective missions and significant achievements in space exploration, including the Mars Orbiter Mission (Mangalyaan) and Chandrayaan missions to the Moon.

howToJoin.title: How to Join ISRO
howToJoin.html: There are multiple pathways to join ISRO depending on your qualifications. Here are the primary entry points:

icrb.title: ISRO Centralised Recruitment Board (ICRB)
icrb.html:
A Beginner's Guide to the ISRO Scientist/Engineer 'SC' Exam (ICRB)

The ISRO Centralised Recruitment Board (ICRB), under the Department of Space, Government of India, is responsible for recruiting scientists and engineers.

1. Introduction: Your Journey to Becoming an ISRO Scientist

If you're dreaming of a career that lets you reach for the stars, you're in the right place. The Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO) regularly recruits bright engineering graduates for the prestigious post of Scientist/Engineer 'SC'. This is a Group ‚ÄòA‚Äô Gazetted post, equivalent to a Class-I officer. This guide will break down the entire process based on the latest advertisement (e.g., No. ISRO:ICRB:02(EMC):2025).

2. Are You Eligible? Checking the Boxes ‚úÖ

Educational Qualification

  • Degree: You need a B.E./B.Tech or an equivalent degree in one of the specified disciplines.
  • Disciplines: Electronics & Communication, Mechanical Engineering, or Computer Science Engineering.
  • Minimum Marks: You must have an aggregate minimum of 65% marks or a CGPA of 6.84/10.
  • Important Note: ISRO is very strict about this. If your university provides both percentage and CGPA, you must meet at least one of these criteria. You cannot convert your CGPA to a percentage to meet the eligibility.

Age Limit

  • The maximum age is 28 years as of the specified cut-off date (e.g., June 16, 2025).
  • Age relaxation is available for categories like Ex-Servicemen and Persons with Benchmark Disabilities (PwBD) as per Government of India rules.
3. The Application Process: Your First Step üìù

Key Dates to Remember

  • Online Registration Starts: Typically in May/June.
  • Online Registration Closes: Approximately 20 days after starting.
  • Last Date for Fee Payment: A couple of days after registration closes.

Step-by-Step Application Guide

  1. Visit the Official Website: Go to https://www.isro.gov.in during the application window.
  2. Register Online: Fill out the application form carefully. You will receive an online Registration Number‚Äîkeep it safe!
  3. Application Fee: You initially pay a processing fee (e.g., ‚Çπ750). This is refunded fully for Women, SC/ST, PwBD, and Ex-Servicemen, and partially (e.g., ‚Çπ500) for other candidates who appear for the written test.
  4. Documents: You only need to upload your photograph and signature. All other documents are required only at the interview stage.
4. The Selection Process: The Two-Stage Challenge üéØ

Stage 1: The Written Test

An offline, objective-type test of 120 minutes with two parts.

PartSubjectQuestionsMarksMarking Scheme
Part ACore Discipline80 MCQs80+1 for correct, -1/3 for wrong
Part BAptitude/Ability Test~15 MCQs20No Negative Marking

Stage 2: The Interview

Shortlisting is done in a 1:5 ratio (vacancy:candidates). The interview is highly technical and graded out of 100 marks.

Final Selection

The final merit list is prepared with 50% weightage to the Written Test score and 50% weightage to the Interview score.

5. How to Crack It: Syllabus & Preparation Strategy üìö

Syllabus Breakdown

  • Part A (Technical): The syllabus is very similar to the GATE syllabus for your respective engineering discipline.
  • Part B (Aptitude): Tests Numerical, Logical, Diagrammatic, Abstract, and Deductive Reasoning.

Preparation Strategy for Beginners

  1. Build Strong Fundamentals: Understand the 'why' behind every concept. Refer to standard textbooks.
  2. Solve Previous Year Papers (PYQs): This is the most crucial step to understand the pattern and difficulty.
  3. Practice Mock Tests: Improve speed, accuracy, and time management.
  4. Don't Ignore Part B: The 20 marks can be a deciding factor.
  5. For the Interview: Be thorough with 3-4 favorite subjects, know your final year project, and stay updated on ISRO's latest missions.
6. Life at ISRO: Pay, Perks, and Posting üöÄ
  • Designation: Scientist/Engineer 'SC'
  • Pay Level: Level 10 of the Pay Matrix
  • Basic Pay: ‚Çπ56,100/- per month (starting)
  • Allowances: Dearness Allowance (DA), House Rent Allowance (HRA), and Transport Allowance.
  • Other Benefits: New pension scheme, excellent medical facilities, subsidized canteen, LTC, etc.
  • Posting: You can be posted in any ISRO Centre/Unit across India.

Good luck with your preparation! A dedicated and structured effort is all you need to achieve your goal.

internship.title: Internships & Projects at ISRO
internship.html:
Your Launchpad to Space: A Complete Guide to ISRO Internships & Projects

1. Introduction: Go Beyond the Classroom üöÄ

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) opens its doors to ambitious students through its internship and project trainee programs. These are immersive experiences that allow you to work on cutting-edge space technology alongside the nation's top scientists and engineers.

2. Two Pathways to ISRO: Which One is for You?

A. The Internship Scheme

A short-term program (max 45 days) designed to give you a feel for the work culture and projects at ISRO. Ideal for gaining a quick, practical overview.

B. The Student Project Trainee Scheme

A longer, more intensive program where you can work on a specific academic project or dissertation. Duration varies from 45 days to over 30 months, depending on your degree.

3. Checking Your Eligibility: Do You Qualify? ‚úÖ

General Requirements for All Applicants

  • Citizenship: You must be an Indian citizen.
  • Academic Performance: Minimum aggregate of 60% or a CGPA of 6.32 on a 10-point scale.

Eligibility for the Student Project Trainee Scheme

DegreeEligibility CriteriaMinimum Duration
B.E. / B.TechMust have completed the 6th semester.45 days
M.E. / M.TechMust have completed the 1st semester.120 days
BSc / DiplomaMust be in the final year of study.45 days
MScMust have completed the 1st semester.120 days
PhDMust have completed all coursework.30 months
4. The Application Process: A Step-by-Step Guide üìù

ISRO's internship applications are decentralized. You apply directly to the specific ISRO centre you are interested in.

  1. Identify the Right Centre: Choose a centre that aligns with your field of interest (e.g., rocket development, satellite design).
  2. Visit the Centre's Website: Each centre has its own "Careers" or "Internship" section with specific guidelines.
  3. Prepare Your Documents: You will typically need a resume, a No Objection Certificate (NOC) from your college, and academic transcripts.
  4. Submit Your Application: Follow the instructions on the centre's website.
  5. Await a Response: Selection is based on academic merit and the availability of projects and mentors.
5. Where the Magic Happens: Meet the ISRO Centres üõ∞Ô∏è

Here are some major ISRO centres that offer student opportunities. Visit their official websites for the most current information and application procedures.

  • Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre (VSSC): Lead centre for launch vehicles. [Website]
  • U R Rao Satellite Centre (URSC): Primary centre for satellite design. [Internship Page]
  • Liquid Propulsion Systems Centre (LPSC): Develops propulsion stages. [Internship Page]
  • Space Applications Centre (SAC): Develops satellite payloads. [Vyom SRTD Program]
  • National Remote Sensing Centre (NRSC): Manages remote sensing data. [Student Eligibility]
  • ISRO Propulsion Complex (IPRC): Tests propulsion systems. [Career Opportunities]
  • Indian Institute of Remote Sensing (IIRS): Premier training institute. [External Student Internship]
  • Master Control Facility (MCF): Manages satellites in orbit. [Internship Page]
  • North Eastern Space Applications Centre (NESAC): Supports the North Eastern region. [Outreach Program]
  • National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL): Autonomous lab for atmospheric research. [Website]
6. Important Things to Know Before You Apply
  • These opportunities are generally unpaid.
  • You must arrange for your own accommodation.
  • A certificate is awarded upon successful completion.
